blocks.text: Divide the base into 10 equal parts, erect the mid-ordinates and tabulate the values as follows:

blocks.latex: A_{1} = \text{mean value of y} = \frac{A_{1}}{\text{sum of products of columns} (b) and (d)} = \frac{1}{5}(88+3(75)+81) = \frac{1}{5}(88+225+81) = \frac{394}{5} = 78.8.
blocks.description: Calculation of the mean value of y based on the mid-ordinates.

blocks.text: Similarly, B_{1} = \text{sum of products of columns} (b) and (d) = 20.

blocks.latex: B_{1} = 20 \text{ (sum of products of columns (b) and (d))} = 2 \times 20 + 30 + 75 = 20 \text{ ( products where the cosine terms begin absent)}.
blocks.description: Calculation for B based on products of mid-ordinates.

blocks.text: Analysis by Method (a) (due to Professor Harrison)... To employ this method we must take at least twice as many ordinates as the largest multiple of B_{1}.
